title: A Tour in Tartan-Land
author: Bede, Cuthbert
snippet: Thankfully we gather together our luggage, amid astorm of supplications from porters and cab-drivers. Wehave been recommended to go to the George Hotel, inGeorge Square; and we incautiously ask the question,how far it may be to that locality.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: Got on to Portsmouth a little after seven. Landed at the George Hotel, where I breakfasted. I should have mentioned that I had previously written to Sir George Grey the intimation of my visit, and had obtained a most gracious reply from him at Wells.

title: Sunny days abroad;
author: [Dyer, Catherine Cornelia (Joy)
snippet: We are at the George Hotel, where an excellent  portrait of Washington greeted us, as we entered the dining-room, and made us feel quite at home, at once.

title: Observations in Europe, principally in France and Great Britain
author: Durbin, John Price.
snippet: The roadfora mile or two out of Perth has fine sidewalks, andwe found many respectable people enjoying their evening promenade, among whom were females, apparently decent and well-behaved, unattended by gentlemen. The town itself had a cheerful look, being well lightedwith gas; and we had a very pleasant night at theGeorge Hotel. There was great commotion in Perth,as had been the case at Edinburgh, in anticipation ofthe queen's visit.

title: A Tour in Tartan-Land
author: Bede, Cuthbert
snippet: Indeed, we found that other meals were treatedwith the same profusion and variety of dishes as thebreakfast; and that reasonable charges were made. Onour return from the Highlands, we again stayed a fewdays in Glasgow, but this time at the George Hotel,where we also met with great comfort and attention, aplentiful table, and reasonable charges. One of thesedays was a Sunday, which day was observed with thecustomary strictness.

title: A university tramp,
author: Hubbell, Orrin Z. [from old catalog]
snippet: It is almost one continual ship yard from its mouth to Glasgow, interspersed with elegant country seats and well kept estates. At last we reached the company's docks, stepped ofl", and once more stood upon land in " bonnie Scotland.' ' Having had our trunks and luggage examined at the dock, by the custom-house officer, we were permitted to pass out and at once drove to the George Hotel, were assigned to our rooms, looked upon the customs and manners of a strange people, and began to realize that the broad ocean rolled between us and the best and fairest  and most progressive land on the face of the earth.

title: Notes in England and Italy.
author: Hawthorne, Sophia Peabody
snippet: preferred even to this a visit to Ellerslie House, upon the lands of which William Wallace was born. But all wishes were vain, for on we went to Glasgow, and drove to George's Square, George Hotel. At the station we were recommended to several hotels, and when I asked our old cabman whether the George was good, he replied with the broadest accent :

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: * Mr. M'Gregor of the George Hotel, Glasgow, lias opened a private hotel at Arroquhar.

title: Abroad. Journal of a tour through Great Britain and on the Continent
author: Coghill, James Henry.
snippet: h. for Melrose, and on arrival stopped at the George Hotel, and procuring a carriage, wedrove some five miles to the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, founded in 1150, by Hugh de Moreville, Lord of Lauderdale, upon a sitewhich was supposed to have been originally a place of Druidicalworship. It was burned to the ground by Edward IL, on hisretreat from his unsuccessful invasion of Scotland, in 1322.

title: Abroad.
author: Coghill, J[ames] Henry. [from old catalog]
snippet: m. for Melrose, and on arrival  stopped at the George Hotel, and procuring a carriage, we drove some five miles to the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, founded  in 1 150, by Hugh de Moreville, Lord of Lauderdale, upon a site which was supposed to have been originally a place of Druidical worship. It was burned to the ground by Edward II., on his retreat from his unsuccessful invasion of Scotland, in 1322.

title: The Existential Detective
author: Thompson, Alice
snippet: He never questioned her. 'I'll meet you at the George Hotel.'
